Award.AwardTitle: ICPALMS a Portal for Standards-based Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The ICPALMS pathway is designed to provide a widget-based portal into content, services, professional development, research, and dissemination that result in a scalable, sustainable infrastructure to support individual and collaborative standards-driven instructional planning with K-12 NSDL resources. It includes standards-based planning tools that recommend relevant digital resources just-in-time and continuously. ICPALMS integrates within the context of teacher practice in Florida, as a test bed, including rigorous alignment with state content standards, but transitions to use the Common Core Standards. Teachers collaborate with other teachers, library media specialists, content specialists and school leaders to create effective plans that integrate NSDL resources. ICPALMS has contributed 3,000 K-12 resources to NSDL. These resources are recommended or created by educators. All resources are vetted through a rigorous review process that involves teams of content, pedagogy, and practitioner experts to ensure that tools, services and the connected content are standards-based, reflect appropriate levels of cognitive complexity and utilize evidence-based instructional strategies tied to improved student outcomes. ICPALMS helps NSDL realize its vision to attain deep and meaningful integration into educational practice. ICPALMS meets challenges repeatedly cited as barriers to wider digital library use, by providing a system to enable educators to wed high quality resources, vetted by experts, with time saving planning tools. ICPALMS makes accessing and implementing digital resources relevant in the day-to-day roles and responsibilities of educators. Integrating the Common Core and other national standards facilitates expanding implementation and expandability into other states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iCPALMS Portal for Standards-driven instruction grant led to significant outcomes that have helped K12 educators during the lifetime of the grant and will continue to do so in years to come. Some of the most significant outcomes of the grant include:

  1. CPALMS site and tools currently average more than 64,000 users on a daily basis to access resources and tools developed by this project. About 63% are from Florida, 27% from the rest of the USA, and 10% from around 200 other countries and territories.

  2. More than 130,000 teachers from all the school districts within Florida use the CPALMS apps and tools. The original grant goal was to reach 5,000 users.

  3. CPALMS served more than 40 million resource downloads since the beginning of the grant.

  4. CPALMS has been adopted by the State of Florida as the official source of information on standards and course descriptions for the state. It is also the official instructional resource repository for the state.

  5. Through this project more than 10,000 teachers were trained on the use of CPALMS and the tools. A series of online tutorials are also now available to replace the face-to-face training workshops we did during the project. The grant goal was to train 1,000 teachers.

  6. This grant has enabled us to create a platform that we built on several other projects that led to developing thousands of additional resources, new tools, additional professional development, and more awareness. More than 50 projects and organizations have utilized this platform and this number will continue to grow.

  7. Through this project, more than 4,000 resources were added and reviewed but the platform enabled creating and publishing more than 11,800 high-quality, standards-aligned, and vetted instructional and educational resources are now published available to teachers and students. The vetting is a rigorous review process that includes expert teachers and subject area expert reviewers for each and every resource. The numbers continue to grow through other projects. The original grant goal was to review 2,700 resources which does not always lead to publishing.

  8. The CPALMS platform has been essential in developing unique resources that are only available and unique on CPALMS. Some of these are: CPALMS Perspectives video series connecting real-life application of the standards, Model Eliciting Activities and engineering lessons, text complexity resources, mathematics formative assessments, original student tutorials, and many others. Each of these collections have hundreds of resources on CPALMS.

  9. Through this project, 12 apps were developed as part of the CPALMS portal. These apps include a curriculum planner (CMAP), resource development and recommendation center, resource review system, standards progression mapping tool, standards visualization tools, and several others. It has also now a platform for other apps that were created on other projects where we have four more apps additional apps in the last two years.
  10. The platform is enabling us to branch different interfaces to support different users. We utilized the CPALMS platform on another grant to develop a student website (FloridaStudents.org) with thousands of student resources that are freely available. The platform is enabling us to serve teachers and students through the grant and allowing us to sustain the system in the future through other projects.
  11. As a result of a separate but related NSF ICORE grant, we have been able to commercialize and license some of our resources and technology.

Overall, we believe we had a very successful project and this grant was a tremendous opportunity for our team but most importantly K12 educators and students who now cherish these tools and resources. The CPALMS platform continue to be freely available to the users and we believe this is a sustainable model for the foreseeable years to come.


Last Modified: 10/21/2016
Modified by: Rabieh Razzouk
